author: Camilla Turner
title: Pushy parents demand children are diagnosed with learning difficulties to get special treatment, teachers say
text:
Pushy parents demand children are diagnosed with learning difficulties to get special treatment, teachers say Pushy parents are demanding that their children are diagnosed with learning difficulties Camilla Turner , Education Editor 24 February 2017 • 12:01am 
P ushy parents are demanding that their children are diagnosed with learning difficulties to get them special treatment in the classroom, a survey of teachers has found. 
Over half of teachers (57 per cent) believe there is widespread misdiagnosis of special education needs (SEN) among children, with the majority saying this is due to “parental pressure”. 
Almost three quarters (72 per cent) of the teachers polled by YouGov said that some parents campaign for their child to be labelled as having a learning difficulty even if there is little evidence to support it. 
Teachers told the survey that parents want to be given a medical or psychological explanation rather than accept that their child is just badly behaved. Parents want a medical explanation rather than accept that their child is just badly behaved, teachers said Credit: altrendo images 
L orraine Petersen, a special needs expert and former chief executive of National Association of Special Educational Needs, said: “Most parents will work on the assumption that the quicker you assess why a child is having difficulties and give him or her a label, the faster you can get extra support. 
“There may also be a sense of relief that comes with being able to ‘blame’ a diagnosed disorder. Parents may think people will be a lot less judgmental of a child's behaviour - and their parenting skills - if they know the child has a label.” 
The poll of 810 teachers, commissioned by GL Assesment, found that 62 per cent said children with genuine need are being overlooked as teacher resources are diverted towards those whose parents have made a fuss. There may also be a sense of relief that comes with being able to ‘blame’ a diagnosed disorder Lorraine Petersen, a special needs expert 
A ccording to figures from the Department for Education, just under a million children in England have a special educational need, 11.6 per cent of the school population, which is down from 18.3 per cent six years ago. 
The decline in England followed a report from Ofsted in 2010 that said as many as a quarter of all children identified with an SEN were misdiagnosed. 
Too many schools, the report said, were using low attainment and slow progress as their main indicators of SEN rather than more robust assessments. 
At one school, all pupils in Year 11 were categorised as SEN because they were at risk of not achieving their expected GCSE grades. At another, those who had parents serving in Afghanistan were labelled as SEN. 
The Ofsted report concluded that children needed better pastoral support and teaching rather than being labelled as special needs. Follow The Telegraph
